best_practices: Use BrandColors for all brand-specific colors to maintain consistency and enable easy theme switching.
Apply NativeWind utility classes for layout, spacing, and responsive design while using style objects for shadows.
Combine NativeWind classes for predictable behavior since React Native does not cascade styles like CSS.
anti_patterns: Hardcoding hex colors directly in components breaks theme consistency and violates brand guidelines.
Using NativeWind color utility classes for brand colors instead of semantic BrandColors constants.
Spreading StyleSheet objects with animated values creates new objects on each render causing performance issues.

faq.question: What is the difference between NativeWind and Tailwind CSS?
faq.answer: NativeWind brings Tailwind-like utility classes to React Native but has limitations. Not all web Tailwind utilities work, and class behavior differs since React Native does not cascade styles.

faq.question: How do I support dark mode with BrandColors?
faq.answer: Import both BrandColors and BrandColorsDark, then use useColorScheme hook to return the appropriate color set based on the device theme setting.

faq.question: Can I use NativeWind for all styling?
faq.answer: Use NativeWind for layout, spacing, and responsive utilities. Use StyleSheet for shadows on iOS and elevation on Android since NativeWind has limited shadow support.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides documentation patterns. It does not access files, networks, or execute any code on your system. All patterns remain in your AI conversation.

faq.question: Why are my NativeWind classes not applying?
faq.answer: Check that NativeWind is properly configured in your babel.config.js. Not all Tailwind utilities are supported in NativeWind v2. Verify class names against the official documentation.

faq.question: How does this compare to React Native StyleSheet?
faq.answer: NativeWind provides utility classes similar to Tailwind CSS for rapid styling. StyleSheet is better for complex reusable styles. Use both together: NativeWind for utilities, StyleSheet for performance-critical and shadow styles.
